abstract.t:
Tagbibs are tiny paperfriendly tags, which expand into multiple BibTags.
Using OCR, they're great for connecting scanned paper with online graphs.
The goal of this spec is three-fold:

ul.li: specify tagbibs: a terse tagdescription which expands into a reversed BibTag
specify tagbibs URI fragments: a way to hint browsers to jump to (bib)tagged content
specify bibrulers: dumb line-based separators for bibtags

section.name: What are tagbibs
section.t: tagbibs allow non-technical humans to write reversed BibTags in a short-form (on paper):
These tagbibs basically tag 'laundry' by expanding into the following BibTags (during parsing/OCR-scanning):

blockquote.t: tagbibs are basically one step up from socialmedia hashtags, allowing mere mortals to connect words to other words using pencil or keyboard.

section.t: There's no precise predicates or properties, which empowers citizen annotation (an essential precursor of RDF).

blockquote.t: syntactically, tagbibs are (concatenated) emaildomains without an extension

ul.li: shell: cat textwithtagbibs.txt | xargs -n1 | awk '/(@[a-zA-Z0-9_@]+)[^ \n]?/ { print $0 }'

section.name: What are tagbibs fragments
section.t: Just like regular URI Fragments they hint the browser to focus anything (Bib)Tagged:

section.name: What are bibrulers
section.t: Bibrulers are linebased separators, used by visual-meta as a means of organizing BibTags:
This snippet would get decoded to this unnested array:
Why not a nested tree-structure? This kneejerk reaction should always be considered 'a last option'.

blockquote.t: Bibrulers don't try to re-invent XML, they are rather promoting dumb, unnested lists, which are much faster/simpler to traverse & implement in all languages.
